dialogue: This watch I got here wa first purchased by your great-granddaddy . It wa bought during the First World War in a little general store in Knoxville , Tennessee . It wa bought by private Doughboy Ernie Coolidge the day he set sail for Paris . It wa your great-granddaddy is war watch , made by the first company to ever make wrist watch . You see , up until then , people just carried pocket watch . Your great-granddaddy wore that watch every day he wa in the war . Then when he had done his duty , he went home to your great- grandmother , took the watch off his wrist and put it in an ol ' coffee can . And in that can it stayed notil your grandfather Dane Coolidge wa called upon by his country to go overseas and fight the Germans once again . This time they called it World War Two . Your great-granddaddy gave it to your granddad for good luck .
label: Neither

dialogue: Unfortunately , Dane is luck wa not a good a his old man is . Your granddad wa a
label: Neither

dialogue: Marine and he wa killed with all the other Marines at the battle of Wake Island . Your granddad wa facing death and he knew it . None of those boy had any illusion about ever leaving that island alive . So three day before the Japanese took the island , your 22-year old grandfather asked a gunner on an Air Force transport named Winocki , a man he had never met before in his life , to deliver to his infant son , who he had never seen in the flesh , his gold watch . Three day later , your grandfather wa dead . But Winocki kept his word . After the war wa over , he paid a visit to your grandmother , delivering to your infant father , his Dad is gold watch . This watch . This watch wa on your Daddy is wrist when he wa shot down over Hanoi . He wa captured and put in a Vietnamese prison camp . Now he knew if the gook ever saw the watch it is be confiscated . The way your Daddy looked at it , that watch wa your birthright . And he would be damned if and slopeheads were gon na put their greasy yella hand on his boy is birthright . So he hid it in the one place he knew he could hide something . His as . Five long year , he wore this watch up his as . Then when he died of disentary , he gave me the watch . I hid with uncomfortable hunk of metal up my as for two year . Then , after seven year , I wa sent home to my family . And now , little man , I give the watch to you .
